1.content:
As I slowly opened my eyes I shrank away from the intense that infiltrated. I waited for a few moments , shadowing my face with my hands until I fully awoke. I was basking in that warm, orange glow made by the light seeping through my fingers when I heard it.

Something was beside me.

I sat bolt upright, my eyes scanning the space around me. I saw nothing that could have moved. I began to relax, my muscles loosening...until the realisation that I wasn't in my own bed.

I was lying on the ground where there was a patch of luscious, green grass. I was surrounded by huge trees that reached up into a blue sky.

Standing up I whirled on the spot feeling a slight breeze nip past my ear. At each direction all I could see were trees.

Where am I?

I pushed off the rising feeling of panic, knowing it would do no good, pulled my hair up into a ponytail and plunged into the trees. I just hoped I was going in the right direction.

After an hour I came to the tree line. Outside of the copse I was greeted with bright blue skies and rolling green hills. It was the most beautiful place I'd seen.

Just in front of me was a crossroad leading of in several directions. In front of it stood a sign with pointed arrows and one that hung above it which read 'Welcome to the Realm of the Blue Tiger'.

I realised I had to make a choice.
1.title: The Realm of the Blue Tiger

11.content:
As I gazed around in the crisp blue skies above me, I saw there was a brown sign that read in bold black letters this way to the castle. My stomach growling, as I have not eaten in days I decided to follow my gut instincts and go. If there is a castle, there is food, shelter, and possibly civilization. Right now, I am just in this wilderness with nothing but towering trees and animals frolicking about like there is not a care in the world. I am not like them. I am human. I have human needs. These must be satisfied.

Traveling along the winding road, I had this inner feeling that maybe I made the wrong decision. I can hear my mother speak in that heavy broken English of hers that I worried excessively. However, mom you know I am always right I wanted to say. How could I respond to her she was not here. I was out here in the middle of nowhere and to talk to someone that was not here was ludicrous. However, I felt that somehow she was here ridiculing me as she always did. I could hear her clamorous laughter piercing my conscious poking fun at me.
Shaking my head, I decided to continue on my path despite the fact that the skies above began to shift in composure. A heavy breeze swept in from the skies above my hair twirled around as if it would just be torn out of the very follicles that held them in place. Something sinister howled in the distance. Its shrieking wails drove a chill down my spine. Did I pick the right path to go? Was it my anxiety or was I really in trouble?
I wanted to turn back and see what other paths lay for me. The road was a complete black abyss. The trees swaggered back and forth their green leaves turning into a sea of darkness. Their thorny branches pricked against my skin almost as if they wanted to harm me. That is crazy I thought to myself. How could trees come to life?
My heart pumped at an accelerated rate. I could hear the vessels in my veins pulsing in my brain. . Sweat glazed my palms as I clenched my fingernails deep into my flesh. A steady trickle of blood went down my bony arms.
Searching my pockets proved fruitless, as I did not have any of my meds with me. Where was I? I cannot move. My legs were planted deep in this immovable surface. Was my fate finally to end my life come true? All those times I wished for deaths sweet kiss to take me yet now I wanted to recount what I previously said. Was there any turning back down to another road? Life has many roads we can take. Had I finally taken my final path? Swirling in from above an ominous cloud of obscurity blurred my vision. I could feel the air in my lungs slowly drain out as if someone actually took a pin and pricked them open. That lightheaded feeling that I only had when I had not eaten in hours took control of my troubled spirit. Meanwhile I wanted to run, scream, and cry anything but all my emotions and movement was frozen in this moment. What would become of me?

12.content:
I follow a well worn path to the left in the direction the sign reads 'Blue Tiger.' As I walk along I try to remember how I got to this strange and beautiful land, but I have no recollection of anything. Nothing. Not even my name.

I become aware of a most intoxicating fragrance in the air around me. I look to the path ahead and can't believe my eyes. Lining both sides of the path are enormous rose bushes teeming with the loveliest blue roses I have ever seen (I assume anyway, since I can't really remember). I run up to the nearest bush and lean in close to smell one of the gorgeous roses. But instead of filling my nostrils with it's heady scent the rose reaches out and bites me on the nose. I jump back abashed rubbing my injured proboscis.

"Keep your nose out of my business," the rose scolds.

"I just wanted to smell you," I reply shocked. I pull my fingers from my nose checking for blood.

"I just wanted to smell you," the rose mocks. "Did it ever occur to you that I am NOT that kind of rose?"

The question catches me off guard, much like the rest of the conversation but I pause to consider it before answering. I must admit I AM rather ashamed of my actions when I think about it. So, I try to apologize to the rose.

"I beg your pardon, good Rose. I am new here and a stranger to your ways. Uh, until this moment, I was under the impression that roses were meant to be smelled."

"Well we most certainly are not! How arrogant to believe that a flower's sole purpose is for your olfactory pleasure! Who do you think you are anyway? The Blue Tiger? Someone needs to teach...,"

I watch amazed as every rose on the bush, and some of the neighboring bushes as well rise up and aim their razor sharp thorns at me. The big bush starts shaking as the little rose gets more and more irate. Suddenly, the rose yells, "Prepare to fire!" Every rose rears back at once moving as a single unit-- thorns glistening in the sun. I have to act now. But what should I do?

121.content:
I say, "But Rose, please wait and listen! I am misunderstood!"

"Very well," Rose says. "Help me understand."

"It's very simple," I say. "Smelling is not an active sense, it's a passive sense."

"I don't understand," Rose says.

"My nose does not go looking for odors. Odors drift into my nose. My nose has no control over it. It's not like my eyes who can choose what to look at. I would sympathize with you if you were complaining that I stared at you because vision is an active sense. But smelling is involuntary. I can close my eyes. I cannot close my nose."

Rose thought about that. "You make a good case. A very good case. And yet, you leave out the part where you approached me closely so you could smell me better. What about THAT?!"

"Ah! You misinterpreted my movement. I wanted to SEE you better, not SMELL you better!"

"Oh. Well... I suppose I have judged you in haste. I'm sorry for any injuries you may have incurred."

"Oh, don't worry about that," I say. "If you would just be so kind as to tell me how to find the Blue Tiger."

The Rose pointed a long tendril and said:

1211.content:
The Rose points a long tendril and says, "Didn't you see the sign?"

"Yes," I say. "I just thought you might have something to add to it."

"What could I add to it? Either that's the way to the Blue Tiger or it isn't. Correct?"

"Yes, but maybe you know something useful."

The Rose stared at me. "Such as what? How to read? How to walk? Can you read and walk?"

"Of course I can read and walk!"

"Then read the sign and walk in that direction."

"Thank you very much," I say, and add under my breath, "for nothing."

I walk on down the road, listening to the humming of the bees. Hmmm. That's an awful lot of bee humming going on. I wonder what they are up to? Or maybe the bees here are just very loud.

"We are no louder than anywhere else," says a small voice and I look around for its owner. "Here, on your shoulder," it says. Sure enough, there is a yellow bee on my shoulder.

"A talking bee!" I exclaim.

"Oh, don't act so excited. The Rosebush talked. If a gold rammed plant can talk, then surely an insect can pull it off. I am a little bit smarter than a Rosebush, you know?"

"No, I didn't know," I say. "I'm in unknown territory here. I don't know what's what."

"Well, the answer to that one is easy. What is what."

"I don't know. What is it?"

"No, it was a statement, not a question," says the bee.

"Huh?" says me.

"It was nice talking with you but I have to go search for a more intelligent conversation now..."

"Wait!" I say. "Do you know anything about the Blue Tiger?"

The bee rubs his chin and says,

123.content:
I cover my face and head with my arms and run the gauntlet of rose bushes. I have to find this Blue Tiger, hopefully he can tell me who I am and what I am doing here. A barrage of flying thorns hit my face and arms feeling like hundreds of bee stings without venom-- thank goodness. Fortunately, it isn't long before I leave the rose bushes behind and emerge into a serene meadow.

I try to shake as many of the rose thorns as I can from my hair and shredded clothes before starting to explore the area. I have perspired during my exertions and the sweat sets my multitude of tiny injuries on fire. I decide to rest in the shade of large tree. There is something strange about this tree but I am in too much pain to give it much attention. I sit down and rest my back against its massive trunk then pull off what's left of my sleeves and use the cloth to dab at my wounds.

"I do believe I hate this place," I confess to the air, on the verge of tears.

I nearly jump out of my skin when my weepy confession is answered in a booming voice from high above my head. "Whatever in the world could make you hate the enchanted land of the Blue Tiger, my child?"

I look up trying to determine the source of the voice when the trunk I am resting against moves. I jump to my feet and dash what I deem a safe distance from the strange animated tree. I look at the trunk more intently and realize it is not a trunk at all but a giant stem. And what I thought was the top of a bizarre tree is really the underside of an enormous flower. As if to confirm for my eyes what my mind has already deduced, the flower bends down and looks me in the eye with its blue-petal striped face. Now I understand; the Blue Tiger. The Blue Tiger is a monstrous tiger lily the size of a tree.

My mind is reeling but it is obvious the Blue Tiger expects a reply. I gather up the courage to speak and say...

"P-p-erhaps hate is too strong a word... uh... S-s-ir... uh... I mean... your Majesty. I mean... your Highness... uh... oh no... please don't eat me. I've had a really bad day."

The giant blue flower snaked its stem low to look me in the eye, "Please, tell me about it stranger."

So I told the Blue Tiger about waking up here with no memories of who I am. I told him about how lost I feel here in this enchanted land. I told him about being attacked by the strange blue rose bushes. The flower nodded its huge petaled head in a sympathetic manner and graced me with a kind smile.

"I apologize for the behavior of my subjects. These are stressful times, my friend. The flowers are at war. Unfortunately you have stumbled into the War of the Roses."

I stood looking at the floral monarch with what must have been an expression of complete shock. I wanted to speak but couldn't formulate the words to convey my thoughts. The Blue Tiger apologized again, this time taking notice of my injuries.

"Bee balm," the flower said, snapping its leaves like fingers.

My heart nearly leapt from my chest when dozens of bees swarmed in the air around me. I scream and try to cover my face while mentally preparing to feel the piercing pain of numerous bee stings. But instead of the expected pain I feel tiny daubs of cool relief all over my extremities. It feels like refreshing raindrops all over my skin. I raise my face to the heavenly caress, shocked to see the bees are the source of my reprieve.

"I-I thought they were stinging me," I stammer.

The Blue Tiger smiled at me and I swear I heard my mini nursemaids laughing. As the bees smear their soothing ointment over all the rose pricks I smile, for the first time since waking up in this bizarre plant world.

"Thank you. That feels so much better," I say, bowing to the bees.

After a moment more of relaxation I ask the Blue Tiger if he knows who I am or what I am doing in his land. The tiger lily appears to think for a heartbeat before replying.

"There is a prophecy about a mindless stranger who shall come one day to end the war."

"You're not going to attack me or eat me are you?" I asked in as stern a tone I could muster, considering I was scared stiff.

"You're not going to try and chop me down are you?" It boomed.

"Of course not," I said. “I was attacked by a bunch of psychotic rose bushes and I was wondering if all the flowers in this land were as rude."

"Ah, I see. I observed you speaking with the roses. I can see a long way off from up here you know. I thought they may have caught you up into one of their little plots. They have been scheming against me for years," replied the giant lily, as it bent itself down to stare me in the face.

"Why on Earth would some roses want to do such a thing against another flower?" I asked.

"Jealousy, naturally. Roses have always enjoyed center stage. Flower shows, lovers, poetry, always about the roses they are. When I grew here, being as unique as I am, I kind of stole their thunder. The name of the realm was even changed to honor me. I'm afraid they have been plotting my demise ever since. Why, they even convinced the bees to ignore me. That is why there is only one of me." I don't suppose you could maybe help me with that?"

"Well, I suppose so," I said. "What did you have in mind?"

12322.content:
"Well, the only way out is to talk to the bees and convince them to pollinate me..."

"Talk to the Bees?" I exclaimed. I was not particularly fond of bees, in fact, I was wary of them.

"Yes. I don't care about the roses. The bees are my only way of continuing my descent. I don't want my beautiful genes to end here"

I would have said no, but the lily looked so withered that I could not take it.

"Fine, I'll help you. I'll convince the bees! Tell me where they are," I said.

The withered look was immediately replaced by an alert stance. "Go right down the path to your left and you'll find their comb, hanging on a large oak tree."

"Done! So if I manage to convince them, what will I get in return?" I asked, feeling surprised about my firm voice despite the fear in me, which was threatening to make my knees quiver.

"Whatever you ask for," said the noble Blue Tiger.

"I want to go back home," I said. I really wanted to get out of this eerily wonderful place.

"You've got yourself a deal!"

I gave a quick nod and went down the path to my left. It had foliage on both sides. This time I was careful enough not to even touch a leaf. If I snapped a twig on the way, I apologised, just in case. I was in enough trouble already and one never knew what could happen next in this strange forest filled with talking flowers and talking bees.

To my relief, leaves and twigs didn't talk and my journey was uneventful. I could see the oak tree and I hurried to it, with my heart beating fast.

I had no idea in mind as to how to broach the subject with the bees. Should I start with a simple hello and begin with talking about their friends - the roses, or about the Blue Tiger... or should I say I'm lost and ask for directions and veer the conversation round to the lonely giant lily? For all this to work, the bees must be really chatty, or else I would be soon finding myself covered with red stings. I never had a word with bees before (I have to admit I had to entertain a sting or two during my last encounter with them). How would they be? All sweet and honey at first and then red and angry? Or indifferent? Or...

By that time the oak tree came into full sight. It was quite large and shady. The next moment my jaw dropped because I had spotted my destination hanging off one of the branches. To my horror, the honey comb was of higher proportions than I had i imagined - at least three times the size of an average honey comb! I felt my shaky confidence slowly leaking out of me.
I concentrated my vision onto the extra large comb to see whether the bees residing in it were also of XL size. To my relief, they were of normal size. But I was sure there lived thrice as many bees than in an average sized comb.

Now what shall I do?

The cubs were irresistible, I bent down to pet one and it fell over. I touched the other one. It fell over too. They lay there without moving so I reached out to prod one with my toe. That's when I realized they were not real, they were stuffed.

"Who in the world would set two stuffed tigers by the side of the road?" I said out loud.

"Are you my new nanny?" he asked.

"No, I'm not. Are you here by yourself? I heard a loud growl only minutes ago. This no place for a boy like you to be alone."

The child tee heed again. "That was me. I can throw my voice and sound like a bear whenever I want to. I scared you, didn't I?'

He reached over to pick up one of his stuffed animals under each arm. "Are you hungry?"

"Very, are you?"

"A little, we have lots of food back at camp. Follow me and I'll give you some. My parents wouldn't mind. My name is Daniel, what's yours?"

"Drusilla. I was admiring the roses by the side of the path when they took offense and started shooting thorns at me. I laid down to avoid them; that's when I saw your two tiger cubs."

I was relieved to know his parents were near-by. "Lead on Master Daniel. I'd like to meet your parents."

While following Daniel through the forest I wondered about his nationality and his background His black wavy hair fell to his shoulders, his, luminous eyes were dark and wide-set. His skin looked white. He had a wide nose, thick lips, and a muscular body. The jeans, long sleeved shirt, and hiking shoes he wore were practical for roaming the forest. All in all he looked well cared for.

We picked our way through fallen limbs and leaves until we reached a wide clearing. One sweeping gaze revealed two large tents with a smaller one in the middle, all arranged in a semi-circle. A fire pit had been dug in front of the middle tent. A stack of wood sat by the side.

Daniel led me to one of the larger tents. "This is where we eat," he said. "The smaller tent is for sleeping."

"What about the other one?" I asked.

"That's their laboratory."

"Their what?" Had I heard right?

"The place where my mom and dad do their testing. They go hunting for specimens and bring them back for testing."

"And while they're hunting they leave you all alone?"

Daniel looked at me like I'd slipped a cog. "I'm not alone, I have Stripey and Bitey."

Land a gotion. I was torn between eating and moving on, or remaining with this delusional child until his parents returned. I decided to stay.

"You smell," Daniel said.

Considering where I had last stepped before the roses shot their thorns at me, I hastily removed my left shoe and carried it outside. Picking up a stick I scraped it as clean as I could. Then I asked for water.

"We save it for drinking," the boy said. "There's a creek over there." Following the direction in which his finger pointed, I came to a narrow but full flowing stream of water.

When I returned Daniel had relinquished his stuffed animals long enough to lay out a spread of fruits, nuts, tack bread and jerky.

"How old are you Daniel?"

"Almost eleven, how old are you?"

Before I could answer we heard a woman's musical voice call out. "Hey, Danny-boy, where are you? Are you playing in the creek again?"

Taking my hand, Danny pulled me outside. "Look everybody, I found a lady."

13.content:
The path to the Dry Waterfall was the only option. If I was to approach the castle, I would need more than the clothes on my back to convince them.

I picked up the pace, invigorated by my dream. There had once been a time when the realm had fields as green as that, framed by the brilliant blue skies. Though it was a time long before I had been born.

The realm was dying; so too was the Blue Tiger. If the Blue Tiger should pass...

I shook the consequences out of my head, but kept the dying realm close to heart. I thought about our people, diminished by hunger and illness, as I pushed onwards.

As I entered the clearing, sadness clawed at my heart as I saw for myself the barren waterfall. I recalled the tales my grandmother had told me, tales a of a woman, who could save them all.

Dare I even think it? Could I be that woman? Could I make the falls come back and save the Blue Tiger, save our lands?

I made my way to the shallow cave that once would have remained hidden behind a curtain of water.

I closed my eyes. At first, I thought I imagined it. Then the humming grew louder, a vibration. I rummaged through the dirt and rocks as I followed the hum to four objects. The vibration stopped, and I lay them out in front of me.

A bronze chalice, engraved with markings.

An aged silver dagger, it's hilt bound in leather.

A large piece of quartz crystal.

A wooden wand, fashioned from an ancient tree.

I knew only one would help me pass the test, and restore the waters once more.

133.content:
I reach out to grab the crystal but as I make contact with it, a spark of blue power erupts from it. I pull my hand away, afraid of what else could happen. I look at my hand to check for any wounds. To my surprise, I find a branding still burning, I can smell my flesh burning away but I don't feel anything. Intricate designs cover my whole palm as the blue flame spreads out into five snake-like tendrils over my fingers, leaving more of that design in their wake. When the flame is done, it descends beneath my skin and now I feel something. Not pain, but.... power..... so much power. As the flame moves to my skull, I can feel it move behind and over my eyes. Suddenly the world goes black, I feel my body falling down, I stop myself with one knee and arm.

"What's happening? What is this?"

"About time you finally found me." A firm female voice sounds off form somewhere within the blackness.

"Who.... who is that? What is this?"

"This... this is what I've had to call home for the last couple thousand years. As to who I am, I'm the blue tiger."

"The blue tiger? But that can not be. You are said to have left these lands, and that you are dying just like the land."

"I didn't leave these lands, I was banished into this infernal rock with the hope that one of the people like you would find me." A million questions now overtake
my mind.

"Someone like me? How do you mean?" I say.

"I have been dying for many years now, the earth can feel it, my power has not been able to protect it from the evil in this world, an evil I've kept at bay and unseen from the eyes of man. The earth is dying from that evil, the Garanar. An ancient form of demon from Karlor. I have been using the earth's life to create hosts. You are a host."

"A host for what?"

"My power. With the power of the earth, I've been able to create humans with the capability to wield my power without being destroyed by it."

"What am I to do with this power?"

"Fight the Garanar. Close the tears in this reality. They grow in number with every passing day."

"What tears, I have not heard anything about these tears or seen them myself."

"No mere mortal can see them, but you can now. There is more in this darkness then you realize, just look around you." I look up, to my right, and to my left.

"I see nothing."

"Look closer." I peer straight ahead. Within the blackness, dim orange lines begin to appear. Hundreds come to my vision, they are all over this world.

"I can not do this alone."

"No, you can't, but as I said, I have created hosts. As in there are more than one of you. The task you have before you is to use these abilities, this sight in particular to find the others, and bring this crystal with you. Together you will become the legion of the blue tiger, and you will revive and protect this world as I have for many a millennia."

"What of the people, shouldn't they be warned of this coming invasion?"

"Yes, the castle is where you must go now."

"What do I tell the king, he'll think of me as a lunatic with the way I'm dressed."

"You fail to realize that you are no longer the same as you once were."

"How do you mean?"

"Point your hand at the cliff here." The blackness disappears and makes way for the real world. I look at the dried out pool and waterfall.

"Repeat after me. Rivnir livnianth"

"Rivnir livianth." The sound of rushing water sounds out from above before barrels and barrels worth of water fall down the cliff that begins to fill the empty pool.

"Look into the pool, see your new self." I walk over to the edge of the pool, and what I see shocks me. All over my body, I have blue markings, my clothes have changed. I now wear armor, it resembles that of leaves but feels as strong as a diamond. My hair now has blue, white and black streaks in it in the same pattern of a tigers coat. My eyes are a bright pale blue.

"You are now a knight of the Blue Tiger. The king would be a fool to refuse an audience with you or to think of you as a looney."

"Wow.... this is incredible. Where is my weapon? That silver dagger is yours, it is called Drangur or demonslayer in the common tongue. That wand is your weapon as well, it's crafted from the elder trees of Hanlien, it's magic can combat that of the Garanar. That chalice, when you drink from it, it shall heal you from any wound no matter how great and cure you of any poison or curse. These are the weapons of A Blue Tiger knight."

"I don't know what to say."

"Do you accept what I ask of you?"

14.content:
I did not know where this road led, but my intuition told me to follow it. All my life I have followed the still small voice that urged me to follow the unmarked or less travel paths. Often these took me away from civilization, but they always guided me to interesting places where I met interesting people.

I was not sure in which direction I moved. It did not matter because eventually the sun would set in the west and I could determine my direction from that.

As I walked I noticed wild flowers blooming on either side of the road. The flowers released the most exquisite scents and their colors seemed to change at random. At first, I thought that was illusion perhaps a trick of the wind or the way the rays of the sun struck them. However, as I progressed toward the distant horizon I realized that the flowers did change color. That they progressed through the color spectrum as a wave progresses to the shore.

Ahead I saw mountains, their snow capped peaks jagged against the blue sky. I stopped for a few minutes to stare at those beautiful crest. Light reflected from ice crystals, at least I think they were ice crystals, giving the impression of halos.

I started to walk again keeping my eyes on the tallest peak. As I walked, I begin to feel hunger and my stomach started to growl.

I don't have any food. What am I going to eat?

I continued to walk until I came to an orchard. This was the most unusual orchard I had ever seen. There were apple trees, pear trees, plum trees, and trees with fruits I could not identify. The orchard was on the right side of the road, so I turned onto a path leading into it. I walked up to a tree and picked a large fruit.
14.title: Follow the unmarked road

choices: You realise it is the tree that is talking
Someone appears from behind the tree
There is a dwarf in front of you
141.content:
I picked an apple hanging from the tree. It was big and red and juicy and looked like the most delicious thing I'd even eaten. Just as I wrapped my mouth around the apple and took a big bite, I heard someone yell.

"Hey!"

I looked up, searching around me. I saw nothing. Was that person yelling at me? I thought. I forget about it and took another bite, crunching on the delicious fruit.

"Hey!" The voice yells again. It sounds gruff and angry.

"Who is that?" I yell back, getting irritated.
141.title: Pick an apple ...

choices: I hear a voice
I see a vision
I smell a nightmare
142.content:
Judging by it's taste and smell, the fruit I picked was a pear, but it's appearance was quite strange. It looked nothing like a pear. It was a perfect sphere and so light in color as to be almost white, although noticeably violet in hue.

I hadn't taken three bites before it began to have an effect on me. "Darn it!" I said. "I should have known it was psychedelic from the odd color."

The orchard began to wobble in my vision. It was as if the trees had become rubbery and were having trouble keeping still. The fruits on the trees rapidly metamorphosed into birds and began flying away from the trees. The pear in my hand became a half-eaten dove looking bloody and disgusting. I threw it down. The grown absorbed it with a soft sucking sound.

The sky was orange and I couldn't remember if it had been blue before. I knew it was supposed to be blue, but maybe it was already orange. It could be sunset or sunrise. I wondered if I was thinking straight. Would I even know it if my mind ceased to function properly?

I started running. I'm not sure why. After a while I stopped, bent over with my hands on my knees, and panted for breath from the exertion.
142.title: The Odd Pear

choices: Head toward the castle
Head toward the waterfall
head to toward the Blue Tiger.
15.content:
Sit down and wait. Hoping someone would come along and give me some idea what was in each direction. It made no sense to me to go trudging along until I knew what was out there. As I sat there I noticed there was something moving in the woods. A squirrel came running across the path and took the path toward the waterfall.

Then a very short man, i guess he would be a dwarf. I tried to get him to talk to me but he just said he was too busy and hurried down the path toward the castle.

Still unsure I heard a roar from the direction that was suppose to be the route to the Blue Tiger.

I am tired of waiting. I get up dust myself off and ....
15.title: I decided to...

choices: Crossed the drawbridge and entered the castle
Called out and asked for permission to enter
threw a stone into the moat.
151.content:
You sprint trying to catch up to the dwarf but even with your long legs and his short he gets to the castle before you catchup.

You stop and look at the buildings before you. It is definitely a large germanic style castle, with high walls and even higher towers topped with turrets. There was a twelve foot wide moat that looked from where I stood surrounded the castle. There was a drawbridge which was currently down.

I followed the path right up to the drawbridge

and then I .....
151.title: Head toward the castle

info.brief_description: Welcome, one and all, to the Realm of the Blue Tiger
info.description:
Welcome, one and all, to the Realm of the Blue Tiger. In this beautiful Realm you will find mystery and intrigue, the likes of which you haven't seen before. Do you dare travel the Realm and seek the Blue Tiger? Do you wish to try and escape the once forgotten land? Journey you way through the Realm, go where you will.

Please keep within the rating and we don't want any erotica, but anything else is welcome. What do you think the Realm of the Blue Tiger holds in store for you? Make your journey, follow your own path....


Thanks for the mention in "Short Stories Newsletter (March 19, 2014)" 
Also for the mention in "Short Stories Newsletter (June 11, 2014)"
